(15) In the past, in the country of KaÅ›mÄ«ra, there was a bhiká¹£u who widely instructed several hundred disciples.
Among them, there were those who attained the four dhyÄnas, those who attained the five higher knowledges, those who attained the fruit of stream-entry, and those who attained arhatship.
At that time, a person from Arsakes came to the country of KaÅ›mÄ«ra, saw the bhiká¹£u's teachings like this, had a mind of faith and joy, and became his disciple.
Before long, he accomplished the five higher knowledges and manifested his spiritual powers in front of the assembly.
The teacher told him:
Although you have attained the five higher knowledges, your mind is still bound and not liberated. Do not manifest your spiritual powers and be self-conceited!
He then became angry with the teacher, thinking the teacher was jealous of his abilities, and thought to himself:
I will return to my homeland and manifest my virtues and sageliness!
He then flew to his home country and appeared in front of the palace of the king of Arsakes, manifesting his spiritual powers and flying there.
The king bowed to him and asked:
What country is the monk from?
The bhiká¹£u said:
I am a person from our king's country. I went to KaÅ›mÄ«ra to study the Way. Now I am returning, wishing to bless the land and repay the kindness of my birth.
The king was overjoyed and knelt for a long time, saying:
I wish the monk would always stay in my palace from today on and accept my offerings.
The bhiká¹£u agreed.

The king personally made offerings, or had the queen and court ladies come. The bhiká¹£u then had lustful thoughts towards the maids. The ministers below knew this and reported it to the king. The king scolded him in return;
The reason the king did not believe it was because he had seen him fly here before.

Before long, the maid became pregnant. The ministers again reported it to the king. The king took the queen as proof and only then knew the truth. He immediately took away the monk's robes and sent him out of the palace. Because he was a monk, he did not inflict any punishment.
A bhiká¹£u went out to travel and robbed people. No one could match him, and the king did not know it was the previous bhiká¹£u. He thought:
Recruiting brave men to capture him.
When he was brought, it was indeed the previous bhiká¹£u. The king asked:
You previously committed lust and said it was a mistake. How can you rob people again?
The bhiká¹£u kowtowed and said:
I am destitute and have no other plan.
The king said:
I originally saw you flying here with spiritual powers, so I could not bear to inflict poison on you.
I will pardon you again. Do not violate my territory again.
He released him to leave.
The bhiká¹£u thought:
It is like going to work as a laborer to seek a living!
He then sold himself.

There was a butcher who made his servants beat the oxen and stab the sheep, doing everything. Later, he made them beat the bones, which splattered and gouged out the face, destroying his eyes, and he could no longer see. He was no longer employed, and his master sent him away.
Then, holding a broken gourd, he went begging in the alleys, eventually becoming a lowly person.
The bhiká¹£u changed like this for several years. The master, with the eyes of the Way, observed and wanted to know his whereabouts. He saw the bhiká¹£u like this, begging in the market of Anxi.
At that time, among the disciples, there were more than five hundred who only studied the five supernatural powers and did not seek to end suffering. The master told them:
You should quickly prepare yourselves. Now we will go together to visit the disciple of Anxi from the past.
The disciples were all delighted and said:
His moral virtue must have greatly flourished.
The master then humbly went to visit him. They all received his spiritual powers and arrived in an instant, staying in front of him.
The master called out his name, and he immediately responded to the master's voice, saying:
Has the upÄdhyÄya come?
The master said:
You have come to visit me on purpose.
The master asked:
What is the reason for this?
The disciple fully explained the details and argued about the offense.
The master said to the disciples:
Obtaining the five supernatural powers is not a firm and solid path, and one cannot rely on it!

When the master said this, the five hundred disciples all attained the six supernatural powers and became arhats. The disciple was ashamed and had no words. The master and disciples all returned to their original places.
(16) In the past, there was a country that was prosperous, abundant, and populous. Another country wanted to conquer it, so they raised an army and went to attack.
The country inside already knew about this, so they mobilized a large army. Those aged 15 and above and 60 and below were all mobilized to fight.

At that time, there was a man who was weaving cloth, and he was approaching 60 years old. His wife was upright but often disrespected her husband. The husband always respected and served other men. The husband said to his wife:
Now I should go, having been ordered to prepare my own weapons and provisions.
Please send me off in time.
His wife gave her husband a five-liter vessel to store provisions, and a weaving shuttle stick one zhang and one chi long.
The wife said:
You take these to fight, there are no other things. If you break this vessel or lose this hemp stick, I will not live with you again.
The husband then took his leave, not thinking about being harmed by the army, but only fearing that he would lose the two things and disappoint his wife.

On the way, he encountered the enemy troops and fought together. When the army was defeated, he was about to retreat. If the two things on the cloth were lost, he would lose his wife's favor. Everyone ran away, so he raised the shuttle stick and held it on his head, facing the enemy and staying alone.
The enemy troops saw him and said:
He is brave!
They did not dare to advance but retreated.
Then the troops of the country were able to reorganize their formation and, with renewed strength, advanced to fight and won a great victory;
The enemy army was defeated, and almost all of them died.
The king was greatly delighted and wanted to reward those who had merit. The people said to the king:
The weaver should be given the highest reward.
The king then called him in and asked the reason:
Why were you alone able to repel the great army?
He replied:

I am really not a warrior. My wife saw that I was going to the army and gave me two things. If I had lost these two things, my wife would have abandoned me and I would not have been able to maintain a household. Therefore, I risked my life to preserve the two things. I repelled the army because of this, and it was not due to my own bravery.
The king said to the ministers:

Although this man was originally afraid of his wife, he was able to save the country in a crisis. He should be given the highest reward. He was appointed as a minister and given treasures, houses, and concubines, second only to the king. His descendants inherited blessings for generations.
This is the worldly cause and condition-obtained.
The Buddha borrowed it as a metaphor. The wife and husband's five-pint vessel and one-foot shuttle-wood are a metaphor for the Buddha bestowing disciples the five precepts and ten wholesome [deeds].

The husband said, If you firmly guard the two things and do not lose them, then you can live with me. This means that if one upholds the Dharma and never violates it, then one can ascend to the hall of the Way together with the Buddha.

Having already been able to repel the army and see the rewards of the fiefdom again is a metaphor for a person who guards the precepts and has his enemies in the present world eliminated for him, and in the next world he will receive blessings and naturally ascend to the heavenly hall.

(17) In the past, in the city of Shravasti, there was a wealthy Brahmin whose wealth was immeasurable and whose intelligence was bright and wise. However, he fell into wrong views and did not believe in goodness, saying:
It is useless!

At that time, Shariputra saw this with the eye of the Way and thought, This elder has great blessings from the past and has become wealthy. He thinks of food and does not create new [good karma], he will certainly return to the three evil paths. He should go and save him.
He then manifested his spiritual powers and held his alms bowl in front of the seat.

At that time, the brahman was sitting to eat. Seeing ÅšÄriputra, he became very angry. He pushed the door, beat him with his hand, and then sat down to eat. He neither invited him to sit nor asked him to leave. After finishing his meal, he washed his hands, rinsed his mouth, took a mouthful of water, spat it into ÅšÄriputra's alms bowl, and said:
Take this and consider it given to you.
ÅšÄriputra said:
May you receive blessings for immeasurable eons.
He then left.
The elder was afraid he would go and complain, so he sent someone to follow him.
ÅšÄriputra returned directly to the monastery, mixed water with mud, and smeared the place where the Buddha had been walking. He said to the Buddha:
He was so stingy that he gave a mouthful of water as alms. I now use it to smear the place where the Buddha walked. May the Buddha walk on it, causing him to receive blessings for immeasurable eons.
The Buddha then walked in samÄdhi.
The elder's spies witnessed all this and reported back to the elder:
The Buddha has abandoned the position of a wheel-turning king, become a monk, and goes begging for alms with his bowl. He is not greedy!
He only wants to save sentient beings!
They explained the details.
The elder greatly regretted his lack of service. The entire family, young and old, went to where the Buddha was to repent and apologize:
We were foolish and presumptuous. Please forgive our grave offenses.
The Buddha accepted their self-surrender and taught them the Dharma. Their doubts were resolved, and they attained irreversibility.

(18) In the past, the country of Parileyyaka was more prosperous than other countries. Real people and spiritual people, down to the nine grades of the unworthy, all possessed morality. The scriptures of immortals and secular books were also complete. There was no lack of gold, silver, grain, silk, and other things. The Buddha often praised it as the country of fame.
At that time, the ninety-six kinds of non-Buddhist paths all discussed together, saying:

The Buddha said that there is nothing in the country that is not possessed. Let us go together to seek what the country does not have. By this means, we can discourage him and make him not sincere. Only then can we obtain his respect and service.
The Brahmins discussed:
We have never heard of this country having a rakshasa ghost. We must deliberately seek it, but it will certainly be unobtainable. This shows that the Buddha's realization of the Way is not correct!
They searched through the streets and alleys, wanting to buy a ghost, but no one had one. The Brahmins were delighted and said:
We have obtained a strategy.
The Heavenly Emperor knew the Brahmins' deceitful plan and immediately came down to transform into a merchant, sitting in his shop as if selling goods.
The Brahmins went through the shops and arrived in front of him. They asked:
Do you have any ghosts for sale?
The Heavenly Emperor said:
Yes, how many heads do you want?
The Brahmins said to each other:
This is empty talk. Where can one obtain a ghost to sell, and speak of how many heads?ğŸ”½The Brahmins said:
We will know when we see it.
I want to get several heads.

The Heavenly Emperor then opened the gate, and suddenly there were several dozen heads of evil ghosts. The Brahmins saw this and were very frightened. Each of them thought of the Buddha's sincerity and all went to the Buddha to take refuge, saying:
Although the country of Polu has all kinds of things, those who go there empty-handed cannot obtain a single thing. Even if they have goods to buy, they cannot get anything.

Using this as a metaphor, this is what the world sees as present. It is like the city of Sarvagamin, which has everything, the four equalities, the six perfections, the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, from the hearers and solitary realizers up to the Tathagata. If there are people who do not cultivate virtuous conduct, they will not be able to obtain anything in Sarvagamin.
If one follows the sage's teachings and restrains body, speech, and mind, it is like having goods, and there is nothing that cannot be accomplished.
(19) In the past, in the country of India, there was a pine temple, in which there were four practitioners who all had the six spiritual powers.
There were four householders in the country, each inviting a monk to be their long-term supporter.
The four monks each went out to teach and transform, one went to where the Heavenly Emperor was,ğŸ”½one went to where the Dragon King of the Sea was,
one went to where the Garuá¸a was,
and one went to where the human king was.

Then the four monks, with the remaining food in their bowls, divided it and gave it to their patrons to eat. It was complete with a hundred flavors, something they had never seen before. Each asked the monk:
Where did you get this?
The monk then explained the details to each of them.
Then the four householders each made a vow.
One said:
I wish to be reborn in the palace of the Heavenly Emperor.ğŸ”½One wanted to be reborn in the sea as a dragon;
one wanted to be reborn as a garuá¸a;
one wanted to be reborn as the son of a human king.
When their lives ended, they all got to be reborn as the four divine kings.

At the same time, they had the thought of wanting to observe the Eight Precepts. They looked everywhere for a quiet place. Only the king of Magadha's back garden was secluded. They all went to the garden and sat under different trees. With a compassionate mind, they observed the precepts and practiced the six contemplations for a day and night.
The next morning, after finishing their affairs, they gathered and spoke to each other. The king of Magadha said:
What kind of people are you?
One person said:
I am the king of the devas.
Another person said:
I am the king of the nÄgas.
Another person said:
I am the king of the garuá¸as.
Another person said:
I am the king of humans.
The four of them shared their origins and were all greatly delighted.
The king of the devas then said:
We all observed the precepts together. Who obtained the most merit?
The king of humans said:
When I was near the garden outside, the sounds of music could still be heard here. I was able to focus my mind in the midst of that. My merit is the greatest.
The king of the devas said:

In my heavenly palace of the seven treasures, with jade maidens and various entertainments, food and clothing are naturally provided. I no longer think of them. Coming from afar, the merit of the complete fast is the greatest.
The king of the garuá¸as said:
What I like is only eating dragons, which is more enjoyable than the five kinds of pleasures. Now being in the same place without any evil thoughts as big as a hair, my merit is the greatest.
The king of the nÄgas said:

Our kind is the food and supply of the garuá¸as. We are always afraid of being eaten and hide in fear. Now being in the same place, sharing death and keeping the complete fast, my merit is the greatest.
The king of Magadha said:
I have a wise minister named PithÄkula. I will invite him to decide the meaning.
He immediately summoned him and told him the matter in detail. PithÄkula then took four kinds of silk - blue, yellow, white, and black - and hung them in the air. He asked the four kings:
Are the four colors in the air different from each other?
The four kings said:
The different colors are indeed obvious!
The minister said:
Is the shadow of the silk on the ground different?
They replied:
It is not different!
The minister said:

Now the four kinds of beings that receive form are each different, like the different qualities of silk colors. Now the fasting of the Dharma aims for a single flavor, like the shadow on the ground having no variations. Now the four honored kings give rise to the intention of the great path, diligently practicing the fasting of kindness, and when they attain Buddhahood, their appearance will also be of a single kind, without any variations.
The four kings rejoiced and immediately attained the eye of the Way.
(20) In the past, there was a wealthy gahapati who had two sons. When the father became ill and was on the verge of death, he entrusted the eldest son, saying:
Your younger brother is still young and does not know anything. Now I entrust you to take care of him well and not let him suffer from hunger or cold.
The father and son sadly took their leave and he subsequently passed away.
Later, the wife said to her husband:
Your younger brother is growing up and will surely harass your family. All the possessions will be divided up. Why don't you get rid of him before he becomes too big?
The elder brother initially refused, but after being repeatedly urged, he followed his advice.
He took his younger brother out of the city to a deep grave, tied him to a juniper tree, and was reluctant to kill him with his own hands. He wanted tigers, wolves, and evil ghosts to harm him.
He said to his younger brother:
You have offended me many times. I will let you stay here overnight to contemplate your mistakes. I will come to welcome you tomorrow.
He then left.
Soon it was evening, and owls, hawks, foxes, and badgers all cried out. The younger brother was terrified and had nowhere to turn. He looked up to the sky and sighed:
In the three realms, is there anyone compassionate who can accept my surrender?
Today I am in distress and fear immeasurable.
At that time, the TathÄgata saw his plea for help and sat upright in samÄdhi, emitting a great light called Removing Darkness, which illuminated the cemetery, instantly becoming very bright.
Next, it emitted a light called Unbinding which reached the child and loosened the bonds, so that his body no longer hurt.
Next, it emitted a light called Satisfying All which the child saw and he was no longer hungry.
Then the Tathagata followed the light to him, had him untie the bonds himself, and said to him:
Where do you want to go?
The child said:
I wish to become a Buddha and deliver all from calamity as the Buddha does today.
He then gave rise to the intention of unsurpassed, true, and perfect enlightenment.
The Buddha expounded the Dharma to him on various essential points, and he attained the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas.
He said to the Buddha:

Although my elder brother had evil thoughts and violated filial piety by harming me, because of this I got to see the Buddha and end the suffering of birth and death. I want to go and repay his kindness.
The Buddha said:
Excellent!
You should know it is time.
He then flew to his elder brother's house using his spiritual powers.
His brother's wife saw him and was ashamed and embarrassed. She said to her brother-in-law:
Although I was bound by the words of my evil wife and children in the charnel ground, because of this event I attained the Way today, all due to my elder brother's kindness!
He spoke the Dharma for his elder brother's wife, and she attained the fruit of stream-entry.
(21) In the past, when the Buddha was the Heavenly King Åšakra, he often descended to make offerings to the Three Jewels, but only MahÄkÄÅ›yapa refused to accept them.
Why is that?
Because his original vow was only to deliver the poor.
Then the Heavenly Emperor devised a skillful means. The couple descended and became an impoverished old couple in a dilapidated grass hut.
At that time, MahÄkÄÅ›yapa entered the city to beg for alms. The Heavenly Emperor and the old couple welcomed him and made obeisance, saying:
We are cold and poor, please accept some coarse food.
KÄÅ›yapa agreed.
He turned over KÄÅ›yapa's alms bowl and filled it with nectar, making its appearance coarse and ugly, but its essence had a hundred flavors.
The palace suddenly emitted extraordinary fragrance and sweetness, and through samÄdhi meditation he knew it was the Heavenly Emperor.
KÄÅ›yapa said:
Your blessings and merits are lofty and vast, why are you not content?
The Heavenly Emperor replied:
The blessings and merits of the Three Jewels are extremely abundant and immeasurable, therefore the wise are never content!
(22) In the past, there was a pine temple in a foreign country, where there were always over a hundred monks studying together.

There was an upasika who was diligent and knowledgeable in the scriptures. Not far from the temple, she would offer food to a monk every day. The monks took turns in order, from the beginning to the end, and then started over again.
Whenever someone went, the upasika would always ask about the meaning of the scriptures. Those who were secretly shallow in their studies often did not like to go.
There was a monk named Mahallaka who became a monk late in life and knew nothing. He was next in line to go for a meal, but he walked slowly and did not arrive on time.
The upasika saw him and said:
This elder is old and walks slowly.
He said this was great wisdom, and with added joy, he prepared delicious food for him.
Pi gave him a high seat and wanted him to expound the Dharma. The monk on the high seat truly did not know anything. He said to himself:
People are foolish and ignorant, truly suffering.
The upÄsikÄ heard this and immediately contemplated it:
Foolishness and ignorance are the basis of the twelve links of dependent arising.
This is the endless cycle of birth and death, leading to various sufferings and afflictions. Therefore, it is said to be extremely painful.
After contemplating this, she immediately attained the path of stream-entry. She then got up and opened the treasure room, wanting to take out cloth to give to the monk;
The monk then got down from the high seat and left, returning to the monastery.
The upÄsikÄ came out but did not know where the monk was. She looked through the gate but still did not see him. She truly thought that he had attained the spiritual powers and flown away.

The upÄsikÄ then took the white woolen cloth to the monastery to seek a monk. The monk, fearing pursuit, hid in the room and closed the door. His teacher, having attained the six supernatural powers, saw the pursuers and thought he had committed an offense.
He then entered concentration and observed that the upÄsikÄ had attained the path of stream-entry. He called MahÄlo to come out and receive the offering.
The teacher explained the details to him, and MahÄlo rejoiced and also attained the path of stream-entry.
(23) In the past, there was an old woman who had only one son. He fell ill and died. They carried him to the charnel ground. She was grief-stricken and could not help herself. She thought:
I have only one son who should take care of me in my old age. But he died and left me. What is the use of my living?
She did not return home and wanted to die together with him. She did not eat or drink for four or five days.
The Buddha, knowing this, went to the charnel ground with five hundred bhiká¹£us.
The old woman saw the Buddha coming from afar, his majestic light shining brightly. She woke up from her drunken stupor, approached the Buddha, bowed, and stood back.
The Buddha said to the mother:
Why are you in the charnel ground?
She said:
World-Honored One!
I have only one child who has abandoned me and passed away. I am deeply attached to him and want to die with him in the same place.
The Buddha said to the old woman:
Do you want your child to live again?
The mother was delighted and said:
Indeed, World-Honored One!
The Buddha said:
Bring some good incense and fire, and I will chant a vow to make your child revive.
He further told the old woman:
You should get fire from a family where no one has died.
Then the old woman went to look for fire. She first asked a person:
Have there been any deaths in your family before or after?
The person replied:
Those who have passed away before are all ancestors.
The houses he asked all said the same, and after asking dozens of houses without daring to take the fire, he returned to the Buddha and said:
World-Honored One!
I searched everywhere for a house where someone had not died, but there was none, so I returned empty-handed.
The Buddha told the old woman:
Since the opening of heaven and earth, there has been no birth without death. It is also good to seek life. Why do you, mother, follow your son in death in confusion?
Her mind suddenly opened up and she recognized the principle of impermanence.
The Buddha then extensively expounded the Dharma for her, and the old woman immediately attained the path of stream-entry;
The countless thousands of people who observed at the charnel ground all gave rise to the intention of supreme, perfect enlightenment.

(24) In the past, in RÄjagá¹›ha, the people were very prosperous. They lived in nine different classes without mixing with each other. There was a place one li away where those with one million in wealth would enter.

At that time, there was a householder who planned to live in the middle. He immediately engaged in business, enduring hardships and frugality, making various plans, for several decades, accumulating up to nine hundred thousand, still short of one million. He became seriously ill and knew he would not recover.
He had a son, seven or eight years old, and told his wife:
When my son grows up, give him the wealth to engage in business extensively, to accumulate up to one million, and he will definitely live in the middle, fulfilling my wish to be alive!
After saying this, he passed away.
After the funeral was completed, he brought his son in and showed him the treasures:
Your father left instructions that you must grow up, accumulate up to one million, and live in the middle of the million-house district.
The son replied to his mother:
Why must it be so grand?
I can just give it to me and live there early.
The mother then gave it to him.
The young man then used his wealth and treasures to make offerings to the Three Jewels and give to the poor. In half a year, his wealth and treasures were all used up.
His mother was worried and strange about what her son had done.
The young man soon fell seriously ill and eventually died.
His mother, having lost her wealth and with her young son also dead, was sorrowful and missed him.
Among them, the richest man was eighty years old and had no son or heir. The young man was reborn in his family as the first wife's son.

After ten months, he was born, upright and intelligent, remembering his past life. His mother herself held him to breastfeed, but he firmly refused to eat. The blue-robed woman who raised him was also the same.
The mother heard that the man had given birth to a son like this and went to see him.
She loved him and immediately held him, kissing him, and he opened his mouth to eat.
The elder was greatly delighted and doubled her wages to have her raise the child.
The elder then discussed with his wife, saying:

My son was born with a nature that others could not hold or feed him, but this wife could hold and feed him. I now want to go and welcome her as my concubine, to raise and care for my son. Is this acceptable?
The wife listened and agreed, so they betrothed her with proper rites and welcomed her. A separate house was built for her, and she was given wealth and provisions without any lack.
The son then said to his mother,
Do you know each other?
The mother was greatly frightened and said,
We do not know each other.
The son said to his mother,
I am your previous son. I took your 900,000 shares and used them for giving. Now we have come together to be the lord of 800 million. Without laboring, we enjoy blessings. What is this like?
When the mother heard these words, she was both sad and happy.
When the son grew up, he transformed 100 million li into the path of Mahayana.
Therefore, it is said:
The correct method is to produce thousands of them, and in each village, build a house to accommodate all the offerings according to the path. This is how a bodhisattva should enter.
(25) In the past, there was a person in a foreign country who planted a lot of white cotton grass. If it was past the harvest time, the color would be lost and it would not be good.
At harvest time, he hired many workers, who worked from dawn to dusk without rest. The host, seeing the workers' hard work, prepared a delicious meat soup and rice for them.

When the soup was almost done, the fragrance spread in all directions. An old owl flew above and dropped some feces right into the soup. The cook saw it and wanted to remove it, but it had already dissolved.
The cook thought:
If I make another soup, it will be too late.
Among the people who are going to eat, there may be impure things.
Considering that a little feces is not enough to spoil the taste, it is edible. I just won't eat it myself.
The guests all came to sit and eat, and the soup was served. The guests, having worked and being hungry, ate the soup. The guests called the cook and asked for good meat to eat.
The cook knew it was impure and feared losing the guests' favor, so he forcefully swallowed it and did not consider it tasty.

The Buddha borrowed this as a metaphor: The sentient beings of the three realms escape from the beauty of desire, but do not see impurity, and are confused and sink in it, just like the hungry man who eats delicious soup. The great bodhisattvas enter birth and death and manifest receiving form, fully understanding impurity, not relishing it or enjoying it, like the cook who forcefully eats the meat and swallows it without tasting it.

(26) Once, Ananda entered the city to beg for alms. At that time, a woman from a family of poisoners went out to draw water. Seeing that Ananda was upright and handsome, she had lustful thoughts towards him. She returned and told her mother:
There is a disciple of Gautama outside. I want you to get him for me.
The mother then summoned the ghost she served to confuse Ä€nanda, and he unknowingly suddenly arrived at her house.
At that time, the mother of the sorcery said to Ä€nanda:
Now I have given you to him, you cannot leave anymore.
Ä€nanda replied:
I will not follow his words.
The mother of the sorcery made a pit of fire and said to Ä€nanda:
Would you rather burn in the fire?
Or would you rather be with my daughter?

Ä€nanda was terrified and single-mindedly focused on the Buddha. The Buddha then extended his hand and remotely stroked Ä€nanda's head. The ghosts in the home of the sorcery saw the Buddha's hand coming through the air, with immeasurable majestic spiritual power, and all fled in a panic, pushing the mother of the sorcery into the pit of fire, where her body was scorched and rotten. Having thus been burned, she was saved.
Ä€nanda immediately returned to where the Buddha was.
Later, the mother of the sorcery summoned the ghosts and spirits and reprimanded them:
You were unable to confuse and turn the disciple of Gautama. Why did you push me into the pit of fire?
The ghosts and spirits replied:

In the past, I joined with PÄpÄ«yÄn and eighty koá¹­Ä«s of followers to the banyan tree to destroy the Bodhisattva. The Bodhisattva pointed his finger at the ground, his fingers were slender and long, and his palms held a thousand-spoked wheel, his majestic spirit was immeasurable. The eighty koá¹­Ä«s of followers all fell upside down and could not regain their original form. Now he has stretched out to come again. We are indeed frightened and cramped, and therefore we scatter and flee, not staying.
We ghosts and spirits always have our own rules. If we act against the middle way, we will think of harming ourselves.
We have known this for a long time. What do you blame me for?
The mother of the Gu poison then knew that the Buddha was the Honored One, immediately took refuge three times, and attained the path of stream-entry.
(27) In the past, by the seashore there were trees, tens of li long. There were over five hundred monkeys.
At that time, on the sea there was a mass of foam, tens of zhang high, like a snow mountain. Following the tide, it came and stayed on the shore.
The monkeys saw it and said to each other:
